label.intro:
The researchers investigated factors that increased millet straw yield in the Case Study on Pearl Millet Growth in the Sahel. In this experiment, there were 48 combinations of treatments to investigate. While still a relatively large experiment, resources are scarce and hence data was limited. As a result, careful design was important, and hypothesis testing was used to validate that the differences found are not random.


They found several treatments and interactions of treatments affected the outcome variable. This was found with the help of hypothesis testing. An extract from the paper, alongside Table 1 that is referred to is given here:


The repeated measures analyses showed that productivity strata defined with the help of the score residuals, genotype, crop residues (CR), and broadcast P application explained a significant proportion of total variation.

There were significant interactions of genotype x year (which may also reflect the change in genotypes) and of genotype x CR for both straw and grain yield. Whereas average straw yields remained similar over years, average grain yields, the effects of stratum on grain yields, and of both CR and P on straw and grain yields, changed over time (Table 1).

The significant p-values indicate that there is enough data to draw reliably that the observed differences in the score residuals, genotype, crop residues, and broadcast application  are not merely due to chance, and instead these variables account for a significant proportion of total variation.
